Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the development of strain sensors using a hybrid film of 1D multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) and 2D graphene. They found that a stable percolation network is formed by 0.18 mg of MWCNTs with a maximum gauge factor (GF) of 1,935.6 and stretchability of 814.2%.
Question_1.Question: What is the maximum gauge factor (GF) achieved with 0.18 mg of MWCNTs?
Question_1.Source: a stable percolation network is formed by 0.18 mg of MWCNTs with a maximum gauge factor (GF) of 1,935.6

Question_2.Context: The study experimented with incorporating 0.36 mg of graphene into the MWCNT film, resulting in a mass ratio of 1:2 between MWCNT and graphene. This improved the GF to 12,144.7 in a strain range of 650–700%.
Question_2.Question: What was the mass ratio between MWCNT and graphene to achieve a GF of 12,144.7?
Question_2.Source: By incorporating the 0.36 mg of graphene into the MWCNT film (i.e., a mass ratio of 1:2 between MWCNT and graphene), the GF is further improved to 12,144.7 in a strain range of 650–700%

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the strain sensing characteristics of MWCNT-, graphene-, and MWCNT/graphene hybrid-based sensors. The MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor exhibited a high GF of 12,144.7 in a strain range of 650–700%.
Question_3.Question: Which sensor exhibited the highest gauge factor (GF) in the mentioned strain range?
Question_3.Source: The strain sensor prepared by spray coating 0.36 mg graphene has the largest GF (~ 34,101.5), but the sensing range is limited to 330%. In contrast, the strain sensor composed of a hybrid of 1D MWCNT and 2D graphene with a mass ratio of 1:2 exhibits both a high GF of 12,144.7 (at a strain range of 650% ~ 700%) and a high sensing range of 710.5%

Question_4.Context: The study evaluated the stability of the strain sensor by subjecting it to 600 cyclic loading–unloading cycles of 500% strain. The signal drift observed during the cycles was approximately 5%.
Question_4.Question: What was the observed signal drift percentage during the 600 cyclic loading–unloading cycles?
Question_4.Source: The signal drift was ~ 5% during 600 cycles.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the photoresponses of MWCNT-, graphene-, and MWCNT/graphene hybrid-based sensors to UV light under different strains. The MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor exhibited a larger response to UV light under all strains tested.
Question_5.Question: Which sensor exhibited the largest response to UV light under different strains?
Question_5.Source: Compared with MWCNT- and graphene-based sensors, the MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensors exhibit a larger response to UV light under all strains tested

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the temperature change of the sensors during UV sensing experiments. The temperature of the sensor surface increased from 24.7 to 36.57 °C under UV exposure.
Question_6.Question: By how much did the temperature of the sensor surface increase under UV exposure?
Question_6.Source: The temperature of the sensor surface increased from 24.7°C to 36.57°C owing to heat transfer from the UV lamp

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the relative current change of the MWCNT-, graphene-, and MWCNT/graphene hybrid-based sensors during temperature changes. The temperature response of the sensor was characterized and compensated according to the measured temperature and temperature responses.
Question_7.Question: What was done to compensate for the temperature changes during the UV sensing experiments?
Question_7.C: The temperature responses were characterized and compensated
Question_7.Source: The temperature response of the sensor was characterized and it was compensated according to the measured temperature and temperature responses

Question_8.Context: The study demonstrated a stretchable photodetector by investigating the photoresponses of MWCNT-, graphene-, and MWCNT/graphene hybrid-based sensors to UV light. The MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor exhibited a high photoresponse of 250% under 0% strain.
Question_8.Question: What was the photoresponse percentage exhibited by the MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor under 0% strain?
Question_8.Source: The MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor can respond to UV light under 300% strain

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the strain responses of the MWCNT/graphene hybrid sensor under cyclic strain in a range of 50–600%. The responses of the sensor remained almost unchanged during the 10 cycles of the loading–unloading process, indicating adequate repeatability.
Question_9.Question: How many cycles of loading–unloading were performed to evaluate the repeatability of the sensor?
Question_9.Source: The responses of the sensor under different strains remained almost unchanged during the 10 cycles of the loading–unloading process

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the durability of the strain sensor by subjecting it to periodic stretch-release cycling under 500% strain. The signal drift observed during the cycles was approximately 5%.
Question_10.Question: What was the strain level used for the periodic stretch-release cycling to evaluate the durability of the sensor?
Question_10.Source: The durability of the sensor was evaluated by periodic stretch-release cycling (500% strain)
